title: New Zealand prop Joe Moody reveals plans to give a 'hiding' in the Rugby World Cup semi final
text:
New Zealand prop Joe Moody wants to relive his childhood and give England a thrashing in Saturday’s semi-final in Yokohama.

Moody, 31, was brought up on watching the All Blacks dish out beatings to the English.

England have beaten New Zealand only seven times in 41 attempts, the last of those wins coming at Twickenham in 2012.

Joe Moody (carrier) set the ball rolling with the war of words ahead of the semi-final

The world champions warmed up for the semi with a 46-14 annihilation of Ireland and Moody wants a repeat performance in the last four.

‘I am pretty sure England copped a few hidings back in the day when I was growing up. Those are always good memories. Hopefully we can repeat another one of those next week,’ he said.

‘You have got to expect that it is going to be tougher each week, no matter who the opponent is. We are just looking forward to the challenge.’

New Zealand were quickly out of the blocks and were 34-0 up before the Irish got their first score. Scrum-half Aaron Smith, who scored the first two tries, said they had more in the tank and Moody agreed.

New Zealand annihilated Ireland 46-14 in Saturday's quarter-final to set up a huge semi-final

Moody says he has fond memories of New Zealand giving England a 'hiding' in past games

‘There were a few areas that we could work on. We lost a bit of pill at lineout so we can tidy that up. Pretty happy with how the scrums went and the backs seemed to be doing the trick when we got them the go-forward. We knew we had to give it to them from the start and not let them build any momentum from that first kick-off. I think we did that.

‘We kept the pressure on for the full 80 minutes. I think we can take some confidence out of it but at the same time it was still a tough game. I don’t think the scoreline reflected how tough that game was.’

New Zealand coach Steve Hansen revealed that Matt Todd, the All Blacks flanker who suffered a shoulder injury on Saturday, is almost definitely out of the England game.

‘It’s unlikely he’ll be available but everyone else is 100 per cent,’ Hansen said. ‘He dislocated it a wee while ago and got a bang on it. We’ll have to wait and see.’
